questions.question: What is BGP?
questions.explanation: BGP: routes traffic between autonomous systems. Purpose: connects ISPs worldwide. Updates: distributed dynamically. Redundancy: multiple paths available. Security: vulnerable to hijacking. Standard: RFC 4271 defines. Complexity: autonomous system management.

questions.question: What is SDN?
questions.explanation: SDN: separates control from data planes. Benefits: flexibility, programmability, cost reduction. Architecture: controllers manage switches. Implementation: OpenFlow protocol. Adoption: cloud providers embracing. Future: network evolution direction.

questions.question: What is QoS?
questions.explanation: QoS: prioritizes network traffic. Purpose: ensures critical app performance. Methods: bandwidth allocation, traffic shaping. Implementation: routers, switches. Challenges: conflicts between priorities. Standards: various implementations exist.

questions.question: What is mesh networking?
questions.explanation: Mesh: every node connects multiple neighbors. Benefits: redundancy, coverage, reliability. Routing: dynamic, self-healing. Scalability: adds nodes easily. Applications: disaster response, rural areas. Challenges: increased complexity.

questions.question: What is multicast?
questions.explanation: Multicast: sends to multiple recipients efficiently. Addresses: 224.0.0.0 to 239.255.255.255. Uses: video streaming, IPTV. Benefits: bandwidth savings. Protocol: IGMP for group management. Challenges: firewall traversal difficult.

questions.question: What is anycast?
questions.explanation: Anycast: packets routed to nearest instance. Uses: DNS, CDN services. Advantage: reduced latency. Implementation: multiple servers, same address. Challenges: connection consistency. Standards: IPv6 native support.

questions.question: What is MPLS?
questions.explanation: MPLS: routes packets using labels. Benefits: fast switching, traffic engineering. Layer: between network and transport. Uses: ISP backbones. Performance: reduced forwarding complexity. Standards: RFC 3031 defines.

questions.question: What is network slicing?
questions.explanation: Network slicing: creates virtual networks. Purpose: service differentiation, isolation. Uses: 5G networks, enterprise. Benefits: resource optimization, security. Implementation: SDN/NFV technologies. Future: essential for 5G/6G.

questions.question: What is zero-trust security?
questions.explanation: Zero-trust: verify every access request. Assumption: breach already occurred. Implementation: microsegmentation, monitoring. Benefits: modern security approach. Challenges: implementation complexity. Adoption: increasing in enterprises.

questions.question: What is network virtualization?
questions.explanation: Network virtualization: software-based networks. Technology: overlays, tunneling. Uses: cloud, datacenters, testing. Benefits: flexibility, cost savings. Challenges: management complexity. Implementation: hypervisors, SDN.
